BILL MOYERS:

111.text:
who would rather you not read them. Here’s

116.text:

238.text: SUSAN CRAWFORD: Thank you so much.

240.text:
BILL MOYERS: “Captive Audience?” Who's
the captive?

243.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Us, all of us. What's happened
is that these enormous telecommunications

248.text:
companies, Comcast and Time Warner on the
wired side, Verizon and AT&T on the wireless

253.text:
side, have divided up markets, put themselves
in the position where they're subject to no

259.text:
competition and no oversight from any regulatory
authority. And they're charging us a lot for

264.text:
internet access and giving us second class
access. This is a lot like the electrification

269.text:
story from the beginning of the 20th century.
Initially electricity was viewed as a luxury.

275.text:
So when F.D.R. came in, 90 percent of farms
didn't have electricity in America at the

281.text:
same time that kids in New York City were
playing with electric toys. And F.D.R. understood

287.text:
how important it was for people all over America
to have the dignity and self-respect and sort

294.text:
of cultural and social and economic connection
of an electrical outlet in their home. So

300.text:
he made sure to take on the special interests
that were controlling electricity then who

305.text:
had divided up markets and consolidated just
the way internet guys have today, he made

310.text:
sure that we made this something that every
American had.

313.text:
BILL MOYERS: But we are a long way from
F.D.R., the New Deal and those early attitudes

319.text:
toward industry. What makes you think that's
relevant now when you come to the internet?

326.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: You know, this is an issue
about which people have a lot of passion because

329.text:
it touches them in their daily lives. “The
Wall Street Journal” on the front page had

334.text:
an article about kids needing to go to McDonald's
to do their homework because they don't have

340.text:
an internet connection at home. Parents around
the country know that their kids can't get

344.text:
an adequate education without internet access.
You can't apply for a job these days without

350.text:
going online. You can't get access to government
benefits adequately, you can't start a business.

356.text:
This feels to 300 million Americans like a
utility, like something that's just essential

362.text:
for life. And the issue of how it's controlled
and how expensive it is and how few Americans

369.text:
actually sign up for it is not really on the
radar screen.

373.text:
BILL MOYERS: You describe this frankly as
a crisis in communication with similarity,

379.text:
you say, to the banking crisis and global
warming. What makes it a crisis?

384.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: It's a crisis for us because
we're not quite aware of the rest of the world.

389.text:
Americans tend to think of themselves as just
exceptional. And we're—

393.text:
BILL MOYERS: Well, we did invent the internet,
didn't we?

394.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: We did, but that was generation
one. Generation two, we're being left far

398.text:
behind. And so all the new things that are
going on in the world, America won't be part

403.text:
of that unless we are able to communicate.
So there's a darkness descending because of

408.text:
this expensive and relatively slow internet
access in America. We're also leaving behind

414.text: a third of Americans. A third of us.

417.text:
BILL MOYERS: In here you call it the digital
divide. Describe that to me.

420.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Well, here's the problem.
For 19 million Americans, many in rural areas,

424.text:
you can't get access to a high speed connection
at any price, it's just not there. For a third

428.text:
of Americans, they don't subscribe often because
it's too expensive. So the rich are getting

434.text:
gouged, the poor are very often left out.
And this means that we're creating yet again

440.text:
two Americas and deepening inequality through
this communications inequality.

445.text:
BILL MOYERS: So is this why, according to
numbers released by the Department of Commerce,

451.text:
only four out of ten households with annual
household incomes below $25,000 reported having

459.text:
wired internet access at home compared with
93 percent of households with incomes exceeding

466.text:
$100,000? These companies are not providing
cheap enough access to the poor folks in this

473.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: These are good American
companies. Their profit motives though don't

477.text:
line up with our social needs to make sure
that everybody gets access. They're not in

482.text:
the business of making sure that everybody
has reasonably priced internet access. That's

487.text:
how a utility functions. That's the way we
need to treat this commodity. They're in the

492.text:
business right now of finding rich neighborhoods
and harvesting, just making more and more

497.text:
money from the same number of people. They're
doing really well at that. Comcast is now

501.text:
a $100 billion company. They're bigger than
McDonald's, they're bigger than Home Depot.

506.text:
But they're not providing this deep social
need of connection that every other country

515.text:
BILL MOYERS: And you make the point that
the United States itself is beginning to experience

519.text: this digital divide in the world.

521.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: It's fair to say that the
U.S. at the best is in the middle of the pack

525.text:
when it comes to both the speed and cost of
high speed internet access connections. So

530.text:
in Hong Kong right now you can get a 500 megabit
symmetric connection that's unimaginably fast

536.text:
from our standpoint for about 25 bucks a month.
In Seoul, for $30 you get three choices of

542.text:
different providers of fiber in your apartment.
And they come in and install in a day because

547.text:
competition's so fierce. In New York City
there's only one choice, and it's 200 bucks

553.text:
a month for a similar service. And you can't
get that kind of fiber connection outside

559.text:
of New York City in many parts of the country.
Verizon's only serving about 10 percent of

563.text:
Americans. So let's talk about the wireless
side for a moment, you know, the separate

566.text:
marketplace that people use for mobility.
In Europe you can get unlimited texting and

572.text:
voice calls and data for about $30 a month,
similar service from Verizon costs $90 a month.

580.text:
BILL MOYERS: Why is there such a disparity
there?

583.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: The difference in all of
these areas is competition and government

587.text:
policy. It's not magical. Without the intervention
of the government there's no reason for these

593.text:
guys to charge us anything reasonable or to
make sure that everybody has services.

597.text:
BILL MOYERS: How do you explain that in
the course of one generation, from the invention

600.text:
of the internet in this country to falling
way behind as you say the rest of the world

606.text: in our access to internet? How did that happen?

610.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Beginning in the early 2000’s
we believed that the magic of the market would

614.text:
provide internet access to all Americans.
That the cable guys would compete with the

619.text:
phone guys who would compete with wireless
and that somehow all of this ferment would

624.text:
make sure that we kept up with the rest of
the world. Those assumptions turned out not

628.text:
to be true. It's much cheaper to upgrade a
cable connection than it is to dig up a copper

634.text:
phone line and replace it with fiber. So the
cable guys who had these franchises in many,

642.text:
most American cities, they are in place with
a status quo network that 94 percent of new

648.text:
subscriptions are going to. Everybody's signing
up with their local cable incumbent. There

653.text:
is not competition for 80 percent of Americans.
They don't have a choice for a truly high

658.text:
speed connection. It's just the local cable
guy. Competition has just vanished.

663.text:
BILL MOYERS: Well, the 1996 Telecommunications
Act was supposed to promote competition and

669.text:
therefore protect the consumer by bringing
prices down. That didn't happen?

673.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: That didn't happen because
it's so much cheaper to upgrade the cable

676.text:
line than it is to dig up the copper and replace
it with fiber. The competition evaporated

681.text:
because Wall Street said to the phone companies,
"Don't do this, don't be in this business."

685.text:
So you may think of Verizon and AT&T as wired
phone companies, they're not. They've gone

690.text:
into an entirely separate market which is
wireless.

693.text:
They're the monsters on the wireless side
that control two thirds of that market. So

697.text:
there's been a division. Cable takes wired,
Verizon/AT&T take wireless. They're actually

702.text:
cooperating. There's a federally blessed non-compete
in the form of a joint marketing agreement

707.text:
between Comcast and Verizon. And so the world
is perfect for them, not so great for consumers

713.text:
who are paying more than other people in the
rest of the world for slower service.

718.text:
BILL MOYERS: Since the 1996 Telecommunications
Act which I thought was going to lower the

722.text:
price of our monthly cable bill, it's almost
doubled.

725.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Well, that's because Time
Warner controls Manhattan. There's no competition.

730.text:
The cable guys, long ago, something they call
“the summer of love,” divided up—

733.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Yeah. They clustered their
operations. It makes sense from their standpoint.

737.text:
“You take San Francisco, I'll take Sacramento.
You take Chicago, I'll take Boston.” And

743.text:
so Comcast and Time Warner are these giants
that never enter each other's territories.

748.text:
BILL MOYERS: You talk to certain people
and they say, "Look, I don't know what this

754.text:
is about. I have all the gizmos I want. I
have a smart phone, I have a tablet,” And

758.text:
they say, "What's the crisis? Because I have
more access than I can use."

763.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: There are a lot of bright
shiny objects that are confusing people about

767.text:
the underlying market dynamics here. What
people don't realize is that for this wireless

772.text:
access you're paying too much and the coverage
is too spotty. On the wired side, that's where

779.text:
we're really being left behind. And here's
the important tie to understand. A wireless

783.text:
connection is just the last 50 feet of a wire.
So fiber policy is really wireless policy.

790.text:
These two things fit together. And if the
whole country did an upgrade to cheap fiber

796.text:
everywhere we'd get better connection for
everybody. Right now though if a mayor wants

801.text:
to do this for himself he'll be pummeled by
the incumbents. In almost 20 states in America

807.text:
it's either illegal or very difficult for
municipalities to make this decision for themselves.

812.text:
BILL MOYERS: In North Carolina a couple
of years ago lobbyists for Time Warner persuaded

818.text:
the state legislature to make it almost impossible,
virtually impossible for municipalities to

826.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: That's exactly right. And
so now North Carolina, after being beaten

830.text:
up by the incumbents is at the near the bottom
of broadband rankings for the United States.

835.text:
BILL MOYERS: And what's the practical consequence
of that?

837.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: All those students in North
Carolina, all those businesses that otherwise

841.text:
would be forming, they don't have adequate
connections in their towns to allow this to

846.text:
happen. They've got-- they're subject to higher
and higher pricing. They're being gouged.

851.text:
BILL MOYERS: Your book did underscore for
me why this is so important to democracy,

858.text:
to the functioning of our political system,
to our role as a self-governing free people.

865.text:
Talk about that a moment. Why do you see this
so urgently in terms of our practically dysfunctional

872.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: We need to be able to speak
to each other effectively and effectively

877.text:
to government. We need to empower our citizens
to feel dignified and ready to cope in the

885.text:
21st century. Having a communications system
that knits the country together is not just

890.text:
about economic growth. It's about the social
fabric of the country. And a country that

895.text:
feels as if it can move together and trust
each other is one that is more democratic.

902.text:
As a matter of national policy we have forced
other countries to talk about the importance

908.text:
of internet access, foreign policy we're great
at saying, "Make sure internet is everywhere."

913.text:
Domestically, for some reason, we haven't
done so well. So I see internet access as

920.text: the heart of a democratic society.

922.text:
BILL MOYERS: You use that merger of Comcast
and NBCUniversal as the window in your book

929.text:
into what this power can do to the aspirations
of a democratic internet.

936.text:
BRIAN WILLIAMS on NBCNightlyNews: Federal
regulators today approved the purchase by

939.text:
Comcast of a majority stake in NBCUniversal
from General Electric […] This merger will

946.text:
create a $30 billion media company with cable,
broadcast, internet, motion picture and theme

952.text:
park components. The deal is expected to close

957.text:
BILL MOYERS: You say that the merger between
Comcast and NBCUniversal represented a new

963.text:
frightening moment in U.S. regulatory history.
How so?

969.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Comcast is not only the
nation's largest broadband distributor with

975.text:
tens of millions of customers, it also now
owns and controls one of the four media conglomerates

981.text:
in America, NBCUniversal. That means that
it has a built-in interest in making sure

988.text:
that it shapes discourse, controls programming
all in the service of its own profit-making

993.text:
machine. As both the distributor and a content
provider, it's in its interest to make sure

1000.text:
that it can always charge more for discourse
we would think isn't controlled by anybody.

1007.text:
So it's a tremendous risk to the country that
we have this one actor who has no interest

1013.text:
in the free flow of information controlling
so much of high speed internet access.

1017.text:
BILL MOYERS: You say the merger created
the largest vertically integrated distributor

1022.text:
of information in the country. So what's the
practical consequence of Comcast having this

1031.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Here's the consequence.
Comcast with the control over its programming,

1035.text:
and also because it works to closely with
the very concentrated programming industry,

1040.text:
can raise the costs of any rival coming in
to provide let's say competitive fiber access.

1046.text:
So Google in Kansas City is having real trouble
getting access to sports content because Time

1052.text:
Warner Cable, the local monopoly player there,
controls that sports content. So Google or

1058.text:
any other competitive fiber provider has to
enter two markets at once. One market to provide

1063.text:
the transport, the fiber, and then also the
programming market. And making programming

1069.text:
more expensive is yet another barrier to entry.
And Comcast can carry that out now.

1073.text:
BILL MOYERS: So what should the F.C.C. do
about that?

1075.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: This is a moment when we
have to separate out content from conduit.

1079.text:
It should not be possible for a local cable
actor or any distributor to withhold programming

1086.text:
based on volume. That's what's going on. The
programmers say, "We'll sell to Comcast cheaply

1091.text:
'cause they're big. But if you're an upstart
we're going to charge you three to four times

1095.text:
what Comcast is paying for the same programming."
That should not be legal. Everybody should

1101.text:
get access to the same stuff at the same price
and they should be announced prices.

1105.text:
BILL MOYERS: What about the argument that
in this modern world there are certain industries,

1110.text:
certain markets, that require an economy of
scale. Critics have said that you're ignoring

1119.text:
the sophisticated economics that govern these
industries.

1123.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: The economics of these networks
did not change when we added a little bit

1126.text:
of digital pixie dust to them. It's still
very expensive to build these networks. Private

1132.text:
actors still don't have an interest in covering
everybody because that's too much of an economic

1136.text:
risk for them. The better route is sensible
oversight. We can learn from our mistakes

1143.text:
in the past when it came to regulatory regimes
that didn't work. But a regulatory regime

1148.text:
is needed without question to make this work
for all Americans.

1151.text:
BILL MOYERS: I have to say this is pretty
strong stuff. Listen to yourself. "Instead

1158.text:
of ensuring that everyone in America can compete
in a global economy, instead of narrowing

1164.text:
the divide between rich and poor, instead
of supporting competitive free markets for

1169.text:
American inventions that use information,
instead that is of ensuring that America will

1175.text:
lead the world in the U.S. in the information
age, U.S. politicians have chosen to keep

1181.text: Comcast and its fellow giants happy."

1184.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: For the last 30 years the
rhetoric of the market being the thing we

1191.text:
all aspire to has in a sense become the collective
vision in America. Our politicians aren't

1198.text:
separate from that kind of understanding.
I think they believe that it's better to have

1203.text:
government stay out of industry. In this particular
place no government intervention is actually

1211.text:
disaster for the country because we leave
so many people behind, we subject ourselves

1216.text:
to the informational control of just a few
giants. The problem for the politicians is

1220.text:
that there's no upside right now to fighting
back. If they do they'll lose their campaign

1226.text:
contributions. We need to get the public interested
in this so that politicians will understand

1233.text:
BILL MOYERS: In your last chapter you describe

JOEY DUREL in Net @ Risk:  We have an out-migration

and I felt it was time for politicians to

1263.text:
RICK KARR in Net @ Risk: Something like

own fiber optic connection to the information
superhighway.

1270.text:
DON BERTRAND in Net @ Risk: We see telecommunications
in the way of Internet, in the way of fiber

1276.text:
connectivity as something that should be available
to everyone.

1280.text:
STEPHEN HANDWERK in Net @ Risk: Just like
water, sewer, electricity, telephone. I mean

1286.text:
JOEY DUREL in Net @ Risk: I think this is
a tremendous opportunity for small business

1292.text:
RICK KARR in Net @ Risk: So what the city

through its municipal power and water company,

BILL MOYERS: How did they get away with
it in Lafayette when as you say they didn't

1307.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: Persistence of a mayor who
very much focused on this and said, "We're

1311.text:
going to get this done." And there wasn't
a statute at that point at the state level

1316.text:
making it illegal. Municipalities have a lot
of assets at their disposal. They control

1320.text:
the rights of way, the access to their streets
and their poles that people need in order

1324.text:
to build these networks. They can condition

1329.text:
network being built. Stockholm did this. They

and schools and police departments. And then

1345.text:
Not that hard, you just draft an R.F.P., request

Cities often also have access to this long

1359.text:
good name behind a bond issue and make sure
that it gets paid back by the subscriptions

1365.text:
to the network over time. It's a great investment
for the city, and that's what Lafayette found

1371.text:
BILL MOYERS: So how is the consumer in Lafayette
situated differently from me here in Manhattan

1379.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: In comparison to where you
are in Manhattan where there's no government

1383.text:
intervention at all, in Lafayette the municipality
is acting as a steward, standing up for you.

1389.text:
It is in fact government's role to stand up
against the ethic that might makes right.

1395.text:
In most of America there is no government
factor keeping these bullies from charging

BILL MOYERS: You describe something in your
book that we've talked about often at this

table. Quote, "The constant easy, friendly
flow between government and industry in the

communications world centered around Washington
D.C." Describe that world.

1414.text:
SUSAN CRAWFORD: It's a warm pond of familiarity.
Everybody knows everybody else. They're all

1418.text:
very nice people, you'd like to have a drink
with them. They go from a job inside the regulator

to a job in industry to a job on the hill,

And it would be-- I talked to a cable representative

regulatory state of affairs. And she looked

BILL MOYERS: Well, you know, the F.C.C.
was supposed to be the cop on the beat of

1451.text:
the communications world. But for example
Michael Powell, who served as F.C.C. chairman

for four years in the mid-2000s, is now the

Meredith Attwell Baker who was one of the

2920.text:
NICK TURSE:
Well, I was. It really changed-- you know,

2925.text:
the project that I was working on. And I think
it changed me in profound ways. I went to--

2931.text:
NICK TURSE:
I went to Vietnam-- you know, with these stacks

2934.text:
of documents. And I was looking for witnesses
and survivors to individual atrocities, the

2940.text:
cases that I had read about. And I went to
these villages. And I talked to Vietnamese.

2947.text:
And I was asking them about one specific spasm
of violence.

2952.text:
But what I'm-- what they kept telling me,
the stories that I kept hearing, what it was

2956.text:
like to live for 10 years under bombs and
shells and helicopter gunships and how they

2961.text:
had to negotiate their live around the American
war, what it was like to have your home burned

2967.text:
down five, six, seven times, and to finally
give up rebuilding it and start to live a

2972.text:
subterranean or semi-subterranean existence
in a bomb shelter and have to-- you know,

2979.text:
to make all these calculations about how to
survive, when to leave the bomb shelter to

2985.text:
forage for food or to find water or to relieve
yourself, when to farm.

2992.text:
And all these decisions could have a profound
affect that your life depended on it and the

2997.text:
life of your family. You had to know-- to
get into the bomb shelter in time, when artillery

3002.text:
started raining down. But you had to get out
of there before the American troops came through

3006.text:
and started grenading the bunkers because
Americans didn't see these as bomb shelters,

3011.text:
they saw them as enemy bunkers that could
be hiding guerillas. And the Vietnamese lived

3016.text:
with this war for 10 years straight. And as
they told me these stories again and again,

3020.text:
I realized that this was really the story
that I needed to tell, the one of Vietnamese

3026.text:
BILL MOYERS:
You called it a system of suffering.

3028.text:
NICK TURSE:
Yeah, I-- you know, with the way that the

3033.text:
American war was engineered, I think it turned
it into a veritable system of suffering.

3038.text:
BILL MOYERS:
Did you encounter animosity, an anger towards

3042.text:
NICK TURSE:
I didn't. And it was one of the most shocking

3045.text:
things to me that-- you know, I would go into
a village. And I would often be the first

3051.text:
American they had seen since the war. And--
you know, I'd ask them to dredge up the most--

3056.text:
you know, horrific events imaginable, the
most horrible days of their lives. And then

3062.text:
I'd ask these people to do it again and again,
to make sure that I got the stories exactly

3067.text:
And afterwards I would be shocked to find
them thanking me. That they would-- they expressed

3073.text:
a great gratitude. They were amazed that an
American knew something of the story of what

3079.text:
they lived through, the story of their hamlet.
And they couldn't believe that someone had

3083.text:
traveled halfway around the world to listen
to this.

BILL MOYERS:
Why are we talking about this? Do you we think

3087.text:
any good is going to come out of resurrecting
the skeletons in the closet and bringing them

3092.text:
out and exposing them in your book or in a
conversation like this?

3095.text:
NICK TURSE:
Well, I'm hoping that it will have some bearing

3098.text:
on the present. You know, the U.S. is, of
course, involved has been involved in constant

3103.text:
warfare in Afghanistan, Iraq, Pakistan, Libya,
Yemen, Somalia. There's you know military

3112.text:
interventions taking place all over the world,
over the last decade plus.

3116.text:
But I don't think that Americans really have
a clear picture of those wars. And what they've

3122.text:
meant for people overseas, what they've meant
to civilians around the world. So I hope that

3128.text:
my book might be able to, you know, to add
to that conversation, to open America's eyes

3133.text:
to what wars mean for people overseas. And
if we're asked to send our brothers and sisters

3140.text:
and sons and daughters to war, I think we
should have some idea of what it means for

3146.text: the sons and daughters of people overseas.

American drone attack.

rumors of an upwelling of support in the town

3212.text:
"Such a move is seen as the only way to retaliate

3218.text:
Our blind faith in technology combined with
a sense of infallible righteousness continues

3224.text:
unabated. It brought us to grief in Vietnam
and Iraq and may do so again with President

3230.text:
Obama's cold-blooded use of drones and his
indifference to so-called "collateral damage,"

3236.text:
otherwise known as innocent bystanders. By
the standards of slaughter in Vietnam the

3242.text:
deaths by drone are hardly a blip on the consciousness
of official Washington.

3247.text:
But we have to wonder if each one -- a young
boy gathering wood at dawn, unsuspecting of

3253.text:
his imminent annihilation, the student picking
up the wrong hitchhikers, that tribal elder

3259.text:
standing up against fanatics -- doesn't give
rise to second thoughts by those judges who

prematurely handed our president the Nobel
Prize for Peace.
